issues.title: Protection from theft
issues.author: kfet
issues.body:
A big contribution to the usefulness and popularity of AirTags (and similar tech) is the ability of their owners to track valuable items (cars, luggage, etc) in case they get stolen from their owners.

With the current specification it seems this use case is not considered, and any criminal with any compatible smart device (iOS/Android) will be allowed to detect such tracking and disable it 30m after stealing valuables.

comments.author: Sn0wfreezeDev
comments.body:
Hi @kfet,

That is one use-case for which these trackers are used, but it has never been the intended use-case. This specification does not make it easier to discover these trackers for thieves. AirTags, Samsung Trackers, Tile, they all rely on Bluetooth. Every simple Bluetooth scanner app can find them. 

The intended use-case was to find your lost valuables and that's where these devices are great at. The added protection against stalking is helpful for people who are in threat of stalking. Stalking can lead to harmful attacks and have already ended up in at least two people getting killed after they have been tracked with an AirTag. The value of any material device should never be higher than the value of human life.

comments.author: kfet
comments.body:
Hello @Sn0wfreezeDev, thanks for responding!

> Stalking can lead to harmful attacks and have already ended up in at least two people getting killed after they have been tracked with an AirTag. The value of any material device should never be higher than the value of human life.

This is implied. However it should not be an excuse to ignore how other use-cases are affected.

I don't think it is an either-or case, we could have both unwanted tracker detection and help on finding stolen property. Just as a very trivial example to start-off such conversation it could be made possible for authorities to recover details of the device used to disable a tracker, it it gets reported as tracking stolen property. If nothing else this could discourage theft.

> This specification does not make it easier to discover these trackers for thieves. 

I think this is not true. This spec will make it trivially easy, by having a tracker work with any smart phone to proactively notify a thief of the tracker's presence, AND allowing it to get disabled, with zero effort on their part, no additional equipment or app required.

At the very least it seem to me the effect on this use case should be acknowledged as a side-effect.

comments.author: mrlnc
comments.body:
> I don't think it is an either-or case, we could have both unwanted tracker detection and help on finding stolen property.

I think [Section 2: Applicability](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers-00.html#name-applicability-2) goes in that direction; unwanted tracking countermeasures are required only for small items (with high potential for misuse). *Find My* enabled suitcases, bicycles or cars (with the tracker *built-in*) could remain silent.

Is my understanding correct?

comments.author: Sn0wfreezeDev
comments.body: Yes that's the way how Apple has internally defined that for participants of the Find My Network already. You can find leaked documents about this online.

comments.author: Guggie30
comments.body: After experiencing the theft of my wallet, I purchased a new one which has the capability of holding an AirTag in it.  I also add AirTags to my briefcase and hide them inside my luggage lining.  I’m concerned that these benefits  will be rendered useless if proposed specifications do not allow for this popular usage.

comments.author: Sn0wfreezeDev
comments.body: We are actively developing an iOS and an Android App that can detect virtually any tracker that is out there. Our goal is stalking and unwanted tracking protection and its a state funded university project. You can already expect that a thieve would be able to find the AirTag in your wallet.

comments.author: kfet
comments.body: You are assuming 100% adoption of your app on all Android and iOS devices. This is not a realistic assumption.

comments.author: Sn0wfreezeDev
comments.body: No, I do not assume that. That's why I am in favor of this proposal, because that will lead to the adoption needed to fight unwanted tracking. However, I assume that knowledgable people that are concerned of unwanted tracking (e.g. politians, journalists, etc.) can inform themselves and use these tools to protect themselves. The same I assume for organized thieves.

comments.author: kfet
comments.body:
>... The same I assume for organized thieves.

Jumping from "it is possible with knowledge" to "everyone will know how to do this" is a huge leap, especially when talking about petty theft, and random un-targeted street crimes, like stealing wallets and suite cases.

I don't see substance so far behind the claim that trackers provide no protection from such crimes, because everyone would already know how to detect and disable the tracker, even without this specification. This is not a realistic assumption for the general public, criminal or not.

comments.author: kfet
comments.body:
> > I don't think it is an either-or case, we could have both unwanted tracker detection and help on finding stolen property.
> 
> I think [Section 2: Applicability](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers-00.html#name-applicability-2) goes in that direction; unwanted tracking countermeasures are required only for small items (with high potential for misuse). _Find My_ enabled suitcases, bicycles or cars (with the tracker _built-in_) could remain silent.
> 
> Is my understanding correct?

Thanks for pointing this out, I read the section, and the intent is unrelated. It specifies the best practices as required for items small enough to be hidden undetected, which absolutely makes sense, but it doesn't address the general concern discussed in this issue, like the fact that a lot of valuables one would hope to recover are small enough to match this requirement - think wallets with IDs and credit cards, or passport holders.

comments.author: gillian-epm
comments.body: Hi Kalin, it’s true that this tradeoff exists, and if you implement this spec this should be taken into consideration. Prioritizing protections against unwanted tracking is the position we (Google and Apple) have taken; as others have commented above, AirTag is specifically intended to be used for tracking lost items, not for recovering stolen items.  Accessory makers who implement the spec should be aware of this tradeoff and understand its implications on the theft detection scenario.

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body:
The question of theft protection vs unwanted tracking was discussed at the first IETF BoF meeting. Notes are there: 

Quote from Eva Galperin summarizes the position of the focus on protecting people: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/minutes-117-dult-202307271630/ 

"Want to push back on the idea that tracking children,
elderly, stolen goods without detection. It's fine for children
and elderly to know they are being tracked. Anti-theft technologies
like this are stalking devices. People are more important than property."

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Closing this issue per above comments.

comments.author: Guggie30
comments.body:
So it’s safe to say that there will be no attempt to develop standards that will prevent unwanted stalking and preserve detection of stolen property?   That is the final verdict?

Doug Gerard

On Dec 11, 2023, at 7:20 PM, Brent Ledvina ***@***.***> wrote:

﻿

Closing this issue per above comments.

—
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://github.com/bdetwiler/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers/issues/3#issuecomment-1851104808>, or unsubscribe<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/BAZIRFMIS2LTNTI27D4V2GTYI6PLZAVCNFSM6AAAAAAXXXR4SWVHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV43OSLTON2WKQ3PNVWWK3TUHMYTQNJRGEYDIOBQHA>.
You are receiving this because you commented.Message ID: ***@***.***>

comments.author: kfet
comments.body:
> The question of theft protection vs unwanted tracking was discussed at the first IETF BoF meeting.

Framing the issue as "theft protection vs unwanted tracking" is inaccurate, as I've commented above. Obviously, the main goal of this effort is to prevent unwanted tracking. There are ways to keep the main focus on fixing unwanted tracking, while addressing theft protection as well.

A naive approach I've suggested in the comments above is for OEMs to keep track of device IDs used to disable tracking, and have those available to authorities, in case a tracker is reported as stolen / attached to a stolen item. This suggestion has its own obvious problems, but it sets the precedent that it doesn't have to be a "VS" argument at all.

comments.author: kfet
comments.body:
Just to develop this suggestion a bit further, a possible approach is to disable tracking, but make available an obfuscated ID of the device used to disable it to the tracker owner. OEMs can record that action, and inform the tracker owner that they are being recorded, if they want to get that obfuscated ID.

The tracker owner can submit the obfuscated ID to authorities, which can request decoding from OEMs, and do further investigation (e.g. locate the device by its real ID, and recover a stolen car) after going trough the state-specific motions to approve those actions (e.g. obtaining a judge order).

comments.author: kfet
comments.body:
Reopening as I am not sure the points above came across clearly in the conversation so far, drowned by discussions around whether this was a valid argument at all to begin with.

Feel free to close again, if there is no will to address theft use cases at all.

comments.author: Guggie30
comments.body:
Ok.  Now we’re getting somewhere.  This is an excellent suggestion.  I’d like to see this developed further.
Doug

On Dec 11, 2023, at 8:08 PM, Kalin Fetvadjiev ***@***.***> wrote:

﻿

Just to develop this suggestion a bit further, a possible approach is to disable tracking, but make available an obfuscated ID of the device used to disable it to the tracker owner. OEMs can record that action, and inform the tracker owner that they are being recorded, if they want to get that obfuscated ID.

The tracker owner can submit the obfuscated ID to authorities, which can request decoding from OEMs, and do further investigation (e.g. locate the device by its real ID, and recover a stolen car) after going trough the state-specific motions to approve those actions (e.g. obtaining a judge order).

—
Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://github.com/bdetwiler/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers/issues/3#issuecomment-1851143648>, or unsubscribe<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/BAZIRFJNYHWRQOL6A3C6EMTYI6VBFAVCNFSM6AAAAAAXXXR4SWVHI2DSMVQWIX3LMV43OSLTON2WKQ3PNVWWK3TUHMYTQNJRGE2DGNRUHA>.
You are receiving this because you commented.Message ID: ***@***.***>

comments.author: ArcticZeroo
comments.body:
> Just to develop this suggestion a bit further, a possible approach is to disable tracking, but make available an obfuscated ID of the device used to disable it to the tracker owner. OEMs can record that action, and inform the tracker owner that they are being recorded, if they want to get that obfuscated ID.
> 
> The tracker owner can submit the obfuscated ID to authorities, which can request decoding from OEMs, and do further investigation (e.g. locate the device by its real ID, and recover a stolen car) after going trough the state-specific motions to approve those actions (e.g. obtaining a judge order).

Definitely a neat idea as far as solving the theft problem goes, but I don't see this solution as being in-scope for this particular spec.

Correct me if I'm wrong, but the platforms used by location trackers are not interoperable and are not required to be as a part of this spec - the spec only outlines a platform-agnostic way for the trackers themselves to advertise their presence, and otherwise there is no communication between platforms (e.g. even after implementation of this spec, my Android phone wouldn't report the location of an AirTag to Apple, but the spec would allow it to detect the AirTag being on my person). 

If my understanding is correct, how would this (obfuscated) device ID make its way to the tracker owner if they are on another platform? There is no way for my Android phone to inform Apple that I've disabled tracking on the AirTag. IMO, there are also negative privacy implications for these platforms to start storing device IDs, especially since this spec is in the context of reducing unwanted tracking.

Further, as far as I can tell, disablement is currently only defined as a physical action, so there is no actual way to figure out which person/device has physically disabled the tracker. The spec would need to define a way to disable an unwanted tracker through bluetooth.

issues.title: Clarification on the threat model of location-trackers
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)


“First, I think it's important to be clear on the threat model
here. The threat from "finder" type location trackers like
Tiles or AirTags comes from the interaction of a number of features,
specifically:

1. They are compact (thus easy to hide)
2. They are cheap (thus easy to obtain)
3. They take advantage of a preexisting infrastructure intended
   for another purpose (the finder network)
4. They have long battery lifetimes (and thus are suitable
   for long-term surveillance)

To contextualize this, consider the counter example of a GPS tracker
like a Garmin inReach, which takes a GPS location and broadcasts it to
a satellite. These cost about $300, have battery life measured in days,
and are several centimeters across, so are hard to conceal. This is
much less useful for both covert surveillance and for finding ones
own items. So, the objective of this work should be to the extent
possible to prevent attacks which are cheaper than buying your
own GPS tracker.”

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body:
It sounds like these are all good nuances to add to the applicability section. Currently that only talks about what makes something "easily discoverable"

> Accessories are considered easily discoverable if they meet one of the following criteria: 
> - The item is larger than 30 cm in at least one dimension. 
> - The item is larger than 18 cm x 13 cm in two of its dimensions. 
> - The item is larger than 250 cm3 in three-dimensional space.

It sounds like the cost/availability, battery life, and connectedness model are all dimensions that would be good to add.

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: This page links to a threat model presented at the first DULT BoF meeting: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/slides-117-dult-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers-rev-e/

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Tagging this with DULT WG label, as this work will continue in that forum.

issues.title: UT detection countermeasures
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)


“Second, I think it's important to consider the situation with
nonconformant tracking tags. There are several attacks here,
including:

1. Modifying an existing tage to make it nonconformant in
   such a way that the countermeasures in this draft don't
   work.
2. Making a new tag which is nonconformant, etc.

I think this framing is useful when considering two different sets
of countermeasures in this design:

1. The "sound maker" feature of having the device make noise when its
   separated and moving (S 3.12.2.1) or when it is located
   (S 3.12.3).

2. The BT-based "this device is following me" feature described in
   S 3.4.3.

The key point I would like to make here is that countermeasure
(1) is potentially evaded without compromising the above invariants.
For instance, maybe I can take an AirTag and disable the speaker
in some way but it will still work for location tracking. Or
maybe I can wrap it in some sound insulating material. Clearly I
can fix the flashing lights. None of this seems like it impacts
the basic tracking functionality, including the surveillance
use case.

By contrast, I don't think it's necessarily feasible to easily modify
the tracker to use some different protocol that would still be
compatible with tracking but harder to detect (e.g., faster ID rotation)
because that would depend on changing the firmware. So that is
a harder attack to mount, especially if the firmware is signed.
Obviously you can burn out the radio or wrap it in a faraday cage,
but that breaks *both* tracking and unwanted tracking detection.
However, it might be able to build a fake tag which violated
these invariants.

My point here is that detection countermeasures need to depend
on properties of the system that are hard to subvert while
having it continue to be functional. “

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Marking this with DULT WG as this will be taken up by that group

issues.title: Overall UT System Description
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)

“Finally, this document really focuses on how to detect unwanted
tracking but doesn't describe how the system as a whole works.
That makes it difficult to understand the overall context and
in particular to determine which invariants in this design are
enforced by the tracking network (and thus presumably harder
to evade) and those which are enforced by compliant tag behavior
(and thus may be easier to evade). A future version of this
document would be more useful if it described how the system
worked in its "as designed" configuration. This would also
allow evaluating its other security and privacy properties.”

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: This this diagram from Roman does a good sub summarizing the overall architecture: https://github.com/rdanyliw/ietf-dult/blob/main/dult-scope.md

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Gonna close this issue, as I think this topic has been well-covered in the first BoF meeting and with Roman's link above.

issues.title: location-enabled state assumptions
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)


S 3.3.
>   The accessory SHALL maintain an internal state that determines when
>   its location is, or has been, available to the owner via a network.
>   This state is called the location-enabled state.

“Are you making any assumptions about who can turn on this state?
E.g., does it have to be a paired device or can it be the network.”

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Good callout! I admit the original thinking is that only the accessory could determine this state, but I don’t see any big concerns about the paired device or the network determining this state. However, in the network-controlled case, I think we’d need the control message to originate from one of the owner’s devices and the delivery to the accessory to be private and secure.

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Closing this issue as there has been no discussion in a few months. Please re-open if you disagree

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Closing this issue as there has been no discussion in a few months. Please re-open if you disagree

issues.title: UT detection and proximity to owner’s phone
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)


>   It is RECOMMENDED that the location-enabled payload is only
>   advertised when the accessory is in the separated state.  The
>   reasoning behind this recommendation is that unwanted tracking
>   detection relies on the Bluetooth LE advertisements emitted while in
>   the location-enabled state to determine if an unknown accessory is
>   traveling with someone who is not the owner.  If the location-enabled
>   payload is advertised only in the separated state, that minimizes
>   false-positive UT alerts.

How does this interact with cases where I have lost something in
a location near my phone (e.g., in my house.  ?

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Good question! One way this could work is that your phone relays the lost item’s location between your own devices, but not over the finder network.

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Closing this as we believe it's been addressed. Please re-open if you disagree.

issues.title: Clarification on term “unlinkable”
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)

S 3.5.
>   The address MUST be private and it MUST rotate periodically and be
>   unlinkable; otherwise, if the same address is used for long periods
>   of time, an adversary may be able to track a legitimate person from
>   carrying the accessory.

Unlinkable to who? You say below that you might use a PRF so it's
linkable by the paired accessory right}?

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: Agreed — perhaps it would be clearer to describe the randomness requirements as opposed to calling it broadly "unlinkable"?

comments.author: yannick-sierra
comments.body: I think the intent is for the addresses to be unlinkable by all but the owner devices, who need a way to recognize their own accessories. Agreed this could be made clearer.

comments.author: siddikaparlak
comments.body: This is clarified in the latest version hence closing this issue.

issues.title: track-ability when in near-owner state
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)


S 3.5.1.
>   When in near-owner state, the accessory SHALL rotate its resolvable
>   and private address every 15 minutes.  This is a privacy
>   consideration to deter tracking of the accessory by non-owners when
>   it is in physical proximity to the owner.

“Can you still track a device in this state?”

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body:
Not 100% sure I follow the question, so gonna try to clarify the intent of the section. In this state, the accessory’s location can still be determined by the owner’s devices (not the network). The unwanted tracking detection algorithms will not track the accessory in this state, because it’s in the near-owner state.

The word “tracking” referred to in the second sentence is for BT-scanner-based tracking that looks for an address that is static over a long period of time (>> 15 min).

So, maybe should rephrase this to:

"When in near-owner state, the accessory SHALL rotate its resolvable and private address every 15 minutes. This is a privacy consideration to deter long-term tracking of the accessory when it is in physical proximity to the owner."

comments.author: ekr
comments.body:
Yes, my question was whether the owner could still track the device using the network. I.e., do nearby devices still publish reports to the network?

With that said, I don't think the use of the term "tracking" with that limited meaning is helpful here. It's all tracking.

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: To answer this question: "do nearby devices still publish reports to the network?" It's up to the network provider how this is done. owner could publish locations to the network directly, just to other devices on their account, or not publish.

issues.title: Threat vectors which could compromise near-owner state configuration
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)

3.8

>  It is important to prevent unwanted tracking alerts from occurring
>  when the owner of the accessory is in physical proximity of the
>  accessory, i.e., it is in near-owner mode.  In order to allow
>  suppression of unwanted tracking alerts for an accessory advertising
>  the location-enabled advertisement with the owner nearby, the
>  accessory MUST set the near-owner bit to be 1 when the near-owner
>  state is in near-owner mode, otherwise the bit is set to 0.  Table 2
>  specifies the values of this bit.

“So here's another example of a potential attack. How hard is it to
persuade a device it is in near-owner state?”

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: The only way an accessory can be put into the near-owner state is by an owner device with valid BT encryption keys to allow for a connection to the accessory. There are ways this could be thwarted (e.g., jailbroken device), of course.

issues.title: Firmware update UT threat vectors
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Thu, 04 May 2023 00:05 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)


> 5.  Firmware Updates
>
> The accessory SHOULD have firmware that is updatable by the owner.

“This seems bad for the reasons above.”

comments.author: bdetwiler
comments.body:
The 'reasons above' that I am interpreting from Eric:

* https://github.com/bdetwiler/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers/issues/6
* https://github.com/bdetwiler/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers/issues/12
* https://github.com/bdetwiler/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers/issues/8

comments.author: ekr
comments.body: Well, more generally, if you can update the firmware, you can cause the tag to just violate all the rules in this document.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: Although I suppose in general, these tag devices need to be benevolent in the first place to participate in this to begin with — implementers could choose to violate the rules in any version, right? It sounds like the danger is that a product that is sold and is known to be compatible with these anti-tracking protocols could later get a malicious update. The question is if that risk is worse than the risk of not being able to update and being vulnerable to an attack due to an unpatched security flaw.

comments.author: ekr
comments.body:
Well, I think that this basically is a function of the overly narrow threat model of this document. which is that it doesn't address how to prevent the creation of a malicious device which uses the network.

See: https://educatedguesswork.org/posts/unwanted-tracking/#the-broader-threat-model

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Propose that we take up this particular issue as part of the DULT WG

issues.title: non-owner controls should only be enabled in separated mode
issues.author: bdetwiler
issues.body:
From Eric Rescorla <[ekr@rtfm.com](mailto:ekr@rtfm.com)>, Sun, 07 May 2023 20:06 UTC
via [unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers-request@ietf.org)


The non-owner controls specified in S 3.12.4 should probably only be
enabled
in separated mode. It would obviously be quite annoying if I could cause any
tag near me to start emitting noise.

comments.author: bdetwiler
comments.body:
Agree that non-owner controls shall only be available when in separated mode.

Below Table 11 in 3.12.4 there is this statement:

“This control point SHALL be available to the platform only when the accessory is in separated state. In all other states, ..."
 
I propose moving this paragraph above Table 11 so it's not as separated from the rest.

comments.author: mrlnc
comments.body:
Hi all, thanks for the clarification here - I'm following the UT discussion and appreciate the public process. I was trying to find out if playing sounds should be possible when the accessory is in *near-owner* state, and I found Section 3.12.3 confusing.

Section 3.12.3 "Sound Maker" currently reads:

> The accessory MUST include a sound maker (for example, a speaker) to play sound ***when in separated state***, either periodically or when motion is detected.
> It MUST ***also*** play sound when a non-owner tries to locate the accessory by initiating a play sound command from a non-owner device when the accessory is in range and connectable through Bluetooth LE.

This section initially gave me the impression that playing sounds is always possible when in-range (both near-owner and separated state), and it seemed to contradict the statement in 3.12.4. Perhaps the Sound Maker section could emphasise that non-owner initiated sounds require the separated state ("when the accessory is in range and ~connectable through Bluetooth LE~ *in separated mode.*")

This issue seems to be the right place to share my confusion :-)

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: PR #118 is attempting to address this issue

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Correction, this PR addresses this issue: PR #157. Closing this issue

issues.title: Pairing and pairing registry
issues.author: bledvina
issues.body:
// originally from josselin=[40life360.com@dmarc.ietf.org](mailto:40life360.com@dmarc.ietf.org) on May 11th, 2023
// via [unwanted-trackers@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers@ietf.org)

1: Pairing

The word "Pairing" is used in various places of the draft and it seems for different meanings. I recommend using "BLE Pairing" to describe the actual BLE Pairing and avoid using the word "Pairing" for other uses. 

For instance, the following paragraph:
3.15.  Pairing registry

   Verifiable identity information of the owner of an accessory at time
   of pairing SHALL be recorded and associated with the serial number of
   the accessory, e.g., phone number, email address.

Should be replaced with something like:

3.15. Owner registry

Verifiable identity information of the owner of an accessory at time of association SHALL be...

issues.title: MAC address format
issues.author: bledvina
issues.body:
// originally from josselin=[40life360.com@dmarc.ietf.org](mailto:40life360.com@dmarc.ietf.org) on May 11th, 2023
// via [unwanted-trackers@ietf.org](mailto:unwanted-trackers@ietf.org)

2: MAC addresses

The following requirement in 3.5:
"""
The Bluetooth LE advertisement payload SHALL contain a resolvable and
   private address for the accessory which is the 6-byte Bluetooth LE
   MAC address.
"""
is out of scope of this document. The scope of the document does not require a specific MAC address format to be used and this should be an implementation choice.

comments.author: bdetwiler
comments.body:
Hi Thank you for this feedback.

The MAC address behavior needs to be defined as this has impact to the privacy of users (see 9.3.1. Stable identifiers 
 For further details). There is also privacy implications on the intervals between rolls (see https://github.com/bdetwiler/draft-detecting-unwanted-location-trackers/issues/33 for further details)

Lastly, since filing this issue we have expanded  the language to:

‘The address type SHALL be set as a non- resolvable private address or as a static device address, as defined in Random Device Address in Vol 6, Part B, Section 1.3.2 of the [BTCore5.4]. ¶ ‘

issues.title: Advertising interval
issues.author: bledvina

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body:
Seems like adding a justification is a good idea! 

Here are some initial thoughts:

On the lower bound of the advertising interval, we probably want to add the fastest possible rate in which BT LE advertises for completeness and consistence. 

On the upper bound of the advertising interval, the reason to have a value that is not too large is:
a. Probability of detection: The longer the advertising interval, the harder it will be to reliably detect if an accessory is traveling with you 
b. User experience: Time-to-connect for non-owner play sound is a function of the advertising interval. I don't think we'd want users waiting a very long time to connect to locate an accessory that may be tracking them

comments.author: josselindlb
comments.body:
Agreed to not provide a lower bound limit.

About upper bound:
Our understanding is that time to discover or time to connect connect increase linearly with the advertising interval at close to medium range and staying under 4 seconds provides acceptable latencies for item trackers.
In the scope of this spec, close to medium range could be assumed and thus a 4s seconds limit could be used. Interested to hear about potential different findings on this.

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Addressing this issue with PR #125

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Closing this one as we merged PR #125. Please re-open if you disagree with language!

issues.title: Availability for law enforcement
issues.author: bledvina
issues.body:
// Originally from alexis@eff.org on May 15th, 2023
// via unwanted-trackers@ietf.org

''''
3.15.3.  Availability for law enforcement

  The pairing registry SHALL be made available to law enforcement upon
  a valid law enforcement request.
''''

Since this a protocol for how a location tracker should behave for proper detection, this section is out of scope. This appears to dictate on what should happen with law enforcement access on what happens *after detection*, thus the protocol completing it's task and afterwards the user deciding on whatever action to take.

I anticipate language about law enforcement would appear somewhere in the usage of user establishing a tracker for use (benign or malicious), but strongly suggest addressing law enforcement access should be stricken from the scope of the specification.

comments.author: zoracon
comments.body: Just leaving a note here that there will be a follow up to this to possibly offer language on law enforcement requests.

comments.author: zoracon
comments.body:
Here is the updated text proposed for law enforcement. So yes, this is in conflict with my previous statement but I was willing to draw it back after a conversation with my colleagues.

"Additionally, unwanted physical trackers should be accountable. Manufacturers should store the bare minimum of information about the phone or account that the tracker is paired to, and they should store it for a time and in a manner consistent with their data retention policies. The information should be made available to others only in response to a valid court order."

issues.title: addition of "Shipment/Package" to accessory category values list
issues.author: bdetwiler

comments.author: gillian-epm
comments.body: Hi Elliot, is it your expectation that the shipping packages would have bluetooth tracking capability built into the package itself?  Or do you expect to be placing a BT tracker into the box?

comments.author: elliotklein
comments.body:
Hi Gillian, Bluetooth monitoring for packages/shipments under the draft spec is very low cost and essentially can provide worldwide location exception monitoring for important packages. In the envisioned use case(s) the device would be placed inside a package (or potentially outside too). The value is more in **exception** monitoring, not "tracking" to know when ETA is missed by package not being in designated geofence or location(s) or other misdirected or lost package event(s) occur to then trigger a notification Ideally, by an appropriate API. 

Most value is for B2B market in monitoring shipment(s)...from high-value medical shipments, to one of a kind samples, vaccines, high value medical or biological tissue samples,, or food products that under pending U.S. and E.U. regulations will need to be location monitored for chain of custody audit and/or food safety.  

Assigning a unique category code can potentially not be only for B2B enterprise markets or other authorized shipment use cases or registered shippers (UPS, US Postal, etc.) where a unique profile is associated with the Bluetooth tag/device to better assure privacy or functionality to prevent unwanted tracking with an appropriate API or interface(s) to be developed or potentially possible in the future.

How long is the time before the unwanted tracking notification becomes active? Working on the assumption that this needs to be early enough to prevent sensitive location data (such as home address) from being obtained, could there be the potential for nuisance triggering in crowded spaces such as public transport? issues.title: Endpoint Validation for FindMy to Prevent Surreptitious Tracking
issues.author: cfossace
issues.body:
Currently, there is no endpoint validation for FindMy, so the FindMy protocol provides transit for ALL traffic, even unwanted or malicious traffic. 

This means is that anyone can use FindMy to place a tracker on someone (that is not an AirTag) **_so it will NOT be detected by Apple's anti-tracking framework._** 

There needs to be some kind of endpoint validation to ensure that only legitimate Apple devices (or trackers that have been developed by official Apple developers using the FindMy Developer Program) are enrolled.   

1) **POC for registering non-Apple endpoints to the FindMy network to be geolocated by FindMy protocol** https://github.com/seemoo-lab/openhaystack


2) **POC for circumventing anti-tracking framework that allows malicious actors to surreptitiously track people** 
https://samteplov.com/uploads/who-tracks-the-trackers/trackers.pdf

3) **Potential Endpoint registration approach that also preserves user privacy** https://petsymposium.org/popets/2023/popets-2023-0006.pdf

comments.author: cfossace
comments.body: More POCs https://github.com/furiousMAC/antitrackingtags

issues.title: Minor clarification on location-enabled state text (section 3.3)
issues.author: maggiedelano
issues.body:
Thanks for your work on this document, and for soliciting feedback.

Minor suggested clarification: in section 3.3, the report says:

> The accessory SHALL maintain an internal state that determines when its location is, or has been, available to the owner via a network. This state is called the location-enabled state.

The use of the verb "determines" is a little confusing here. I think what you mean is it "detects" when the location is, or has been, available. Determines to me implies that the internal state itself is controlling whether it is in the location-enabled state.

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Thanks, @maggiedelano! We pushed this PR to address your issue: PR #144

issues.title: Supporting active scanning for unwanted tracking
issues.author: maggiedelano
issues.body:
Thanks for your work on this document, and for soliciting feedback.

I did some research on Apple AirTags last year, and one of the things that surprised me was how difficult it was to detect an AirTag using a [standard bluetooth scanner](https://www.maggiedelano.com/2022/02/21/apple-airtags-active-scanning.html) on iOS. It was much easier on Android, and unless it has changed recently there is no way to actively scan for AirTags on iOS (although it was in a beta at some point?). There are many contexts where a user would prefer to be able to actively scan their environment for unwanted trackers, rather than relying on a passive notification (which can take hours to occur).

I understand that platform issues are out of scope for this document, so I'll focus my other comments more specifically here too. Could the authors share the above concerns/suggestions with the relevant iOS team?

This document proposes an advertisement payload (section 3.4) that would allow "platforms to easily scan for and detect the location-enabled Bluetooth advertisement" (section 3.6). From what I can tell this is close to what AirTags already do. A few questions/comments:

- Will the service data TLV be standardized across location trackers? (I'm assuming yes but part of that section is marked TODO)
- It would be helpful to have some context on what existing location trackers already do and how/whether this is codification of what existing trackers e.g. AirTags already do, vs. a new proposed advertisement packet. I think the existing one works fine but the iOS platform is an issue for active scanning right now as I discuss above.
- I think section 6 should encourage (if not require) platforms to support both active and passive scanning. There should also be some discussion about appropriate time frames for passive notification (getting notified hours later is not helpful, but at the same time false positives need to be avoided).

comments.author: siddikaparlak
comments.body:
Thanks for your feedback.

Yes, the service data TLV will be standardized as explained in the latest version.

This draft focuses on the practices and protocols to enable the detection of unwanted trackers. Implementing or providing tools for active scanning is a choice up to the platforms and not in the scope of this draft.

issues.title: Charter: expanding definition for other system aspects
issues.author: zaeddinger
issues.body: Expand definition of charter to include other system aspects, not just the behaviors of separated BLE trackers, particularly methods that tracking networks could deploy.

comments.author: ekr
comments.body:
I'm not quite sure what this issue is about. However, I think what's relevant is whether the specification defines a complete system. Specifically:

1. Does it describe a system which is sufficiently complete to analyze the privacy properties (rather than having a privacy-critical opaque blob)
2. Is it sufficient to create an interoperable system so that a third party could make a tracker which worked with an existing network.

My view is that (1) is imperative and (2) is very desirable.

comments.author: dkg
comments.body:
There is also the problem that the current system depends on a large number of users operating "finder" nodes, in many cases without any awareness that they are doing so, or what the implications are.  If these "finder" operators are critically important for the utility of the trackers, as well as enablers for unwanted tracking, there is an open question about what their incentives and liabilities are for participating in the overall protocol.

For example, a finder operator might be unwilling to operate their finder node unless they could ensure that they were only using them for conformant trackers, which gets into questions like #47 and #63.  If the protocol cannot offer the finder operator that level of nuance, some operators may prefer to not participate in the network at all.

issues.title: Charter: Not having access to a phone is a concern
issues.author: bledvina
issues.body: Not having access to a phone is a concern. Brought up by Ted Hardie.

comments.author: dkg
comments.body:
no access to a phone is a concern in several different directions:

- A modern, up-to-date, well-maintained mobile device can be expensive, and is not necessarily available to everyone who wants one.
- A person who is the target of stalking or other abusive surveillance may have a (not unreasonable) concern that their phone is itself compromised to spy on them, so they might not want to carry it with them everywhere.  If they leave it behind, how can they then detect conformant unwanted trackers?
- When anyone wants to temporarily disable their own phone (or loses it, or runs out of battery, or they turn off bluetooth to conserve battery, etc), their own paired bluetooth devices will switch to "separated" mode, which is easier for a network of detectors to track than "near-owner" mode.
- It's also a problem in terms of false alerts: temporarily disabled phone → "separated" mode peripherals → warnings for anyone traveling with the person whose phone is off.

comments.author: dkg
comments.body:
not clear what "disable" means here -- during the BoF, there was discussion about how Tile trackers can have this particular protocol disabled by their owner (making them directly non-conformant).  but you could also imagine the victim of unwanted tracking looking for a protocol-defined way to disable the device entirely when it is discovered.

The other question is whether it is possible for the device owner to disable some subset of capabilities of any given tracker (e.g. putting chewing gum in the speaker that is expected to make a audible alert when triggered).  Should the charter attempt to address or at least enumerate these risks, and what the implications are for the efficacy of this protocol?

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body:
Good point that this is not well-defined :-)

I think "disable" is intended to mean a mechanism available to a person who finds an unwanted tracker in which they can disable its remote location capabilities (e.g.., BT crowd-sourcing) so that the owner of it can not get location updates. For example, this could be removing the battery, pressing a button on the accessory, etc.

issues.title: Charter: attestation in or out of scope
issues.author: bledvina
issues.body: some parties proposed attestation should be in scope and others proposed it should be out of scope for charter.

comments.author: ekr
comments.body: I don't think this is the right question. Attestation is a technical mechanism. The question to ask is whether fake trackers are part of the threat model.

comments.author: dkg
comments.body: i agree with @ekr here that attestation specifically isn't the right goal here.  I'm not sure what "fake trackers" means, though.  If there is any question about whether a tracker device is conformant or non-conformant (see #47), the charter needs to be clear about how that conformance or non-conformance is assessed (or not!) by other players in the ecosystem.

comments.author: ekr
comments.body:
@dkg, you're right that I wasn't being clear.

The charter and the associated draft contain a set of requirements for how trackers are supposed to behave. These requirements are essential to providing the detection capability claimed by the specification. By hypothesis, trackers manufactured by "legitimate" vendors will be conformant and therefore detectable. The question I am trying to get at is whether it is possible to build a non-conformant tracker that will nevertheless be able to participate in the tracking system but is not detectable. That's what I meant by "fake" but hopefully this is a clearer statement.

I'm distinguishing this from the question of modifying a "legitimate" tracker because one might imagine a system in which:

1. Tracker vendors attested to conformance in some non-technical way
2. There was a technical attestation that a given tracker was manufactured by one of the aforementioned vendors.
3. That attestation was checked prior to letting that tracker participate in the network.

This would be intended to prevent other vendors from just making nonconformant trackers and having them accepted. In this case, it would be the "legitimate" vendor's responsibility to ensure that the tracker was hard to modify and if it were determined that it was easy to do so, that would be a vulnerability they should fix, but the protocol wouldn't engage with that other than, potentially blocklisting trackers of that model/vendor. I'm not saying this is a good system, as I prefer not to rely on trusted hardware; I just think it's a different threat.

issues.title: Charter: Specify what types of devices are in-scope for DULT protocol
issues.author: nacho319
issues.body:
It was noted in some of the earlier documents, but its not mentioned in the current charter - what devices are in scope.  

If I leave my phone somewhere, I would really rather not have a protocol by which anyone can disable it.

I would note an interesting distinction between my phone and a simple tracker: my phone doesn't need the support of other devices to know its location or tell some service where it is located beyond a transport network.  That's not a sufficient distinction for my headphones, though.  They need the support of crowd devices.  I would say that any device that does NOT require the support of crowd devices should be immediately out of scope; I don't think that's practical here.  If we want to talk about protocols to disable LoJack devices, we should do that explicitly.  I also think this distinction aligns with some thinking from dkg about possible liability.

I would like this to be in the charter to avoid future rat hole discussions.

comments.author: bledvina

Our thinking is that portable devices such as phones, watches, tablets, and laptops are not accessories which we want to provide unwanted tracking protection for within the scope of this charter.

@nacho319 how does this sound to you?

issues.title: IETF is a Standards Body and not a Regulatory Body
issues.author: cfossace
issues.body: One thing I think that is important to point out is that the IETF is a standards body and not a regulatory. Body. This means that the standards we are creating are a recommendation at most.  It is currently relatively easy to create a tracker that will be nonconformant to the exisiting protocol, so I think we need to make sure that nonconformant trackers are not supported by the protocol, and will not be able to benefit from the protocol, since there is no regulatory body that would be able to enforce the standard we implement.

comments.author: zaeddinger
comments.body:
Agreed that IETF is not a regulatory body :)

I believe item 5 in the program of work partially addresses this:
_Design mechanisms to ensure that devices that do not correctly implement or adhere to the DULT protocol can be detected and excluded from being trackable via crowdsourced location networks._

We could include in the scope the option to address the non-technical aspects (e.g., providing correct instructions on how to disable the tracker) in a solution. 

I also assume that there are other standards that have a similar issue -- wonder if there's a good example of how others have figured out how to handle this.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: It seems that proposed charter is trying to focus on having technical ways to prevent non-conformant devices from participating, which is I believe the right approach, and also inline with @cfossace's comment (that these are technical standards not regulatory goals).

comments.author: cfossace
comments.body:
So, one way to make sure that items that are non-conformant do not benefit from the protocol is doing endpoint authorization. https://petsymposium.org/popets/2023/popets-2023-0006.pdf

The authors would be happy to discuss this. The authorization would still be privacy preserving.

Engagement may need to be different than typical IETF practice, as those stakeholders may have less experience with protocol development and not all may be able to engage directly on publicly-archived fora. Liaisons, surveys and briefings/feedback sessions may be useful.

issues.title: What is in scope
issues.author: ekr
issues.body:
I want to make sure we agree on what we are trying to do. Here's my understanding:

  -  Standardize the protocols used by (1) the tag to communicate with finding devices (2) the tag to communicate with devices when apparent unwanted tracking is detected (e.g., to cause it to beep).
   - Not standardize the protocols use by the finding device to report to the tracking network (e.g., to upload to iCloud), the protocols used to initialize the tag, or the protocols used by the tag owner to query the network for location.

One way to phrase this is that it ought to be enough to allow you to build your own tag that would work with the network, assuming it had the right keying material.

Does that sound right? If so, I can provide some text to try to sharpen this

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body:
@ekr for item (1) "the tag to communicate with finding devices", just to be clear, I see two components of the BT advertisement packet that are relevant and in scope:

a. BT advertisement header that indicates information like this is used for finding, it operates on a particular finding network, and some status info (e.g., is it near owner or not). We want to specify format, data contents, and security/privacy requirements for this as this is key to interoperability for UT detection
b. BT advertisement payload (part of the advertisement after the header) which will contain finding-network specific information. We definitely want this to be in scope in the sense that its security and privacy requirements need to be defined, but the specifics on the format and data contents of the payload will vary from finding network to finding network. 

Does this align with your thinking?

comments.author: ekr
comments.body:
No, this does not match my expectation. I believe the entire system including the format of the payload needs to be defined in order to permit security analysis of the system as a whole. I suppose it's possible that we might be able to describe the abstract contents minus the encoding, but i think the contents need to be specified, not just "here's an opaque blob plus some security and privacy requirements".

It's unfortunate that we didn't manage to flesh this out in the meeting.

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body:
Agreed it's a bummer we didn't flesh this out.

Another way I could see addressing this would be to specify a baseline (e.g., reference design) finding network protocol for item (1) which would include the full contents of the BT advertisement along with security and privacy requirements for the entire header + payload. Do you think that could work?

comments.author: ekr
comments.body: I don't think that this works because we still won't be able to say anything meaningful about the security and privacy properties of anything which doesn't use the reference design. ISTM that the point of designing something in this space is so that we can say "if you do what it says in this spec, then you will have the following properties". That doesn't mean that there's no room for individual variation, but it needs to be straightforward to evaluate whether an implementation meets a given requirement, and that's not the case if it's an opaque blob with some overall requirements.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body:
@ekr I think I'm on the same page as you for the protocol needing to specify the full advertisement (both the unencrypted and encrypted parts). Looking at the charter definition for the program of work section 1, what specific parts are missing? Maybe just getting your suggested text would be easiest.

> 1. Develop a standards-track protocol ("DULT protocol") between tracking accessories and nearby devices, which may:
> - Specify requirements and a baseline algorithm for determination of unwanted tracking
> - Allow a tracking accessory to identify & advertise its presence when in a detectable mode, using standard formats defined for the underlying transports (e.g., Bluetooth, Near Field Communication, etc.)
> - Allow a nearby device to trigger behavior on an unwanted tracking accessory to aid in determining its physical location
> - Allow nearby devices to fetch additional information about a tracker accessory, including such things as tracker image asset(s) and physical disablement instructions
> - Add privacy and security requirements for all messages used for advertisement, interactions with crowdsourcing networks, and owners of accessories

comments.author: ekr
comments.body:
It seems like the missing text is something like:

"Completely specify the message formats used between the accessory and the finding device".

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body:
@ekr how about this modification to the list? Trying to work it in without sounding awkward.

> 1. Develop a standards-track protocol ("DULT protocol") between tracking accessories and nearby devices, which will:
> - Specify requirements and a baseline algorithm for determination of unwanted tracking
> - Specify complete message formats for accessories to advertise their presence to nearby devices, for one or more underlying transports (e.g., Bluetooth, Near Field Communication, etc.)
> - Allow nearby devices to trigger behavior on an unwanted tracking accessory to aid in determining its physical location
> - Allow nearby devices to fetch additional information about a tracker accessory, including such things as tracker image asset(s) and physical disablement instructions
> - Define privacy and security requirements for all messages used for advertisement, interactions with crowdsourcing networks, and owners of accessories

issues.title: MAC address language improvements
issues.author: bledvina
issues.body:
From Yannick Sierra:

In the next revision of the document, I think it would be good to work together to add some clarifications on the following points:
- Clarify if the owner recognizable data in the payload replaces or augments the matching of the MAC address in the “owned accessory identification". If it replaces the MAC, then we should clarify the requirements on the MAC address.
- Clarify the section 6.1.1. and 6.1.2. in "owned accessory identification” to include a length and offset for the matching when using data from the payload along describing the matching as a byte comparisons.
- If the data in the payload replaces rather than augments the MAC comparison, we should have a requirement that the matching must be over 46bit minimum, so the probability of the platform of mis-categorizing an accessory as “Owned” remains low.

issues.title: Printing Non-SN Unique Identifiers
issues.author: cstapl
issues.body:
3.14 & 3.14.1 

Strong concerns that we’re making an allowance for vendors to opt out of printing the unique identifier in an easily accessible location on the physical device. It’s my understanding that those identifiers are a critical part of the physical evidence in law enforcement response to unwanted tracking related calls from victims, and in the prosecution of such cases. Recommend we discuss this issue with victim advocacy groups, and consider requiring all identifiers to be printed on the physical device.

issues.title: Owner Registry - Storage Duration
issues.author: cstapl
issues.body:
Re: 3.15.2 

In circumstances that indicate someone is possibly concerned the accessory has been used for unwanted tracking, e.g. upon NFC tap or other owner lookup that indicates the victim has physical access to the accessory (like a button push), we should consider extending the duration of the owner registry storage so that the victim has enough time to engage with the systems required to secure the owner information, e.g. law enforcement and the courts. This is another topic that is important to engage with victim advocacy groups on, for their expertise.

pulls.title: Open to Third-Party Developers
pulls.author: Sn0wfreezeDev
pulls.body:
The current version of the document needs to clarify how a platform handles third-party developers. 
We want to ensure that platforms must not limit access to accessories following unwanted tracking specifications. Third-party developers must be able to scan for accessories, connect to them and interact with them over the accessory non-owner characteristic. 

The current version of the document is based on Apple's tracking detection for iOS, which is an excellent solution for most people. Nevertheless, there may exist different target groups that have different needs. For example, a police officer can be required to perform a detailed scan of the environment to detect any nearby trackers. It would be possible for a third-party developer to implement such a service and offer it on the App Store / Google Play Store. 

Furthermore, users might need more detailed settings. A user that has previously experienced stalking might want to be alerted earlier and is okay with experiencing a higher false-positive rate. 

Therefore, I propose the added changes to ensure that no platform or manufacturer limits access to the Bluetooth accessories following this specification.

comments.author: bdetwiler
comments.body:
Hi @Sn0wfreezeDev 

Thank you for the feedback.

The primary goal of this internet draft is to outline the protocols and standards for location-tracking accessory makers to comply with platforms' unwanted tracking services. The "Platform Support for Unwanted Tracking” section is intended to standardize the model where accessory makers shall make a software extension available for the platforms to allow owner’s of their accessories to suppress UT alerts from their own paired accessories.

comments.author: bdetwiler
comments.body: Thank you for this PR. As noted above, these additional requirements are beyond the scope of this document. If there are additional ideas in this area, please open an issue for discussion.

comments.author: Sn0wfreezeDev
comments.body:
I see that this might go beyond the current scope. Unfortunately, I know that Apple is blocking certain Bluetooth advertisements from third-party applications. There may be valid reasons to do so and that's why I tried to implement a section that would disallow platform owners to block the advertisements and access to other data sent out by these trackers. 

As you might already know, we are developing the AirGuard app that is used to perform the currently missing tracking detection for a variety of trackers: Samsung SmartTag, Tile, Chipolo + Find My Trackers on Android. 
When platforms can detect these automatically, we are more than happy because it brings protection to more people. However, there may be issues where a platform integration might lack support of specific features, like manual scanning. My approach to opennes was to ensure that these features can be implemented by third-parties, like us or other people.

pulls.title: Jb pairing address
pulls.author: josselindlb
pulls.body:
Hi there,

I was not sure how much bundling is usually done in PRs, so I ended up bundling some, especially as these are related in some cases. This PR provides addresses the following:

1. Disambiguate "Pairing" and use "association" instead where applicable (issue #17 ).
2. Not require a given MAC address format (issue #18 ).
3. When not in separated mode, require to rotate the MAC "at least every 120 minutes" instead of "every 15 minutes": the rational is that 120 should be good enough so we don't really need to require 15 minutes (of course 15 mn would be allowed).
4. Make the "Paired (Associated) Accessory Identification" mandatory instead of optional for platforms to support: the rational is that the experience would be poor if this is not supported by platforms.

Thanks,
Josselin

```suggestion
4. Design mechanisms to ensure that devices that do not correctly implement or adhere to the DULT protocol can be detected and excluded  from being trackable via crowdsourced location networks.
```
I don't understand why this is out of scope.

comments.body: @ekr looks good to me. Wanna approve the PR and then we can merge?

```suggestion
The goal of the DULT WG is to standardize a protocol for information exchange between location-tracking accessories and nearby devices, along with actions that these accessories and devices should take once unwanted tracking is detected. This protocol is intended to help protect people against being unknowingly tracked by allowing arbitrary devices to detect unwanted tracking by these accessories. The protocols and interactions between devices may be limited to certain states or modes, such as the accessory being separated from a paired/owner device.
```

pulls.author: bledvina
pulls.body: Attempts to address issue #108

comments.author: ekr
comments.body:
Well, I guess I don't really understand what the relevance of this scoping is. Like, what are the special characteristics of smaller tags that would lead to requirements you wouldn't want to impose on tags in bicycles? 

My bigger point is that suppose you say "tags in big but cheap item X don't need to conform" and then it turns out that the way people tag cheap item X is by making the same transponder and just gluing it to X, so you can take it out and use it for tracking.

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: I am thinking of this less as cases where there are requirements we wouldn't want to impose on large objects (bicycles), but rather that if there are features that are _not_ supported by the protocol that are needed for the very small devices (like triggering sounds or fetching a picture) that the work of the WG may not have satisfied the primary use case.

comments.author: ekr
comments.body: OK, I can live with the current text, I guess,

I think this "end-to-end" language is a bit confusing. Let me see if I can flesh out the intention here. 

- Standardize the protocols used by (1) the tag to communicate with finding devices (2) the tag to communicate with devices when apparent unwanted tracking is detected (e.g., to cause it to beep).
- Not standardize the protocols use by the finding device to report to the tracking network (e.g., to upload to iCloud), the protocols used to initialize the tag, or the protocols used by the tag owner to query the network for location.

One way to phrase this is that it ought to be enough to allow you to build your own tag that would work with the network, assuming it had the right keying material. 

Does that sound right?

Now that I see this written down, I'm not sure how helpful it is. I get that we're not worried about someone dropping a bicycle in my backpack, but what's restricting this to small accessories getting us?
I think there's a way to say "small things that could be slipped into a bag unnoticed" without having the charter define sizes in centimeters.

@ekr we actually are proposing to remove "standardize an end-to-end platform-based unwanted tracking detection system or  " in PR #117. That being said, I like your clarifications. However, I think they are not strictly in scope of this particular issue #108. Want to open another issue to track clarifications of what's in vs not in scope?

```suggestion
The WG will not define requirements for interactions between accessory manufacturers and law enforcement. The focus of the WG will be on solving the use case of detecting small and not easily-discoverable accessories, supporting any functionality that is necessary for identifying and recognizing such accessories.
```

@ekr does this help explain why the focus would be on the use cases for small devices? Effectively, this lets the protocol work include things like ways to trigger playing a sound or getting a picture of what the accessory looks like, which isn't necessary for the bike case.
I think it depends on whether the tag is removable, right?

What depends on being removable? I think the main point is to have the focus of the development be on these kinds of devices, and make sure that if there needs to be a way to fetch a URL to get a picture of the device or a command to trigger a sound, those are scoped in.

pulls.author: bledvina
pulls.body: See issue #109

comments.author: tfpauly
comments.body: @bledvina can this be closed in favor of #111?

comments.author: bledvina
comments.body: Closing because PR #111 addresses the issue addressed in this PR.

This feels like a funny juxtaposition. The rest of the text in this graf is very clear about what we are going to do in that the BT SIG is a concrete thing. But like "GBV experts" is not a clearly specified group

I would argue that the text in PR#111 is sufficient, or maybe "will consult with GBV specialists throughout the process and vet with them prior to publication"
I was also thinking PR #111 (BTW, @ekr, see how I re-worked based on @tfpauly feedback) is sufficient to address this issue.
Anyone disagree with being able to close issue #109 based on PR #111?

111 suggests that gender-based violence experts should just be consulted at the end of the process before publication to confirm efficacy. That's specifically contrary to the agreement in the meeting that we want to work with these advocates and experts throughout the standardization process.

@npdoty what about this revised version:

4.  WG will work closely with gender-based violence experts to incorporate their input and feedback. Before deciding to publish the protocol the WG will:
	* Carry out a threat analysis and security analysis 
	* Gather implementation experience
That looks better to me. I think this is more in the spirit of what we discussed at the BoF.
Okay, closing this PR per above comments

pulls.title: consolidate the list of design goals
pulls.author: cfm
pulls.body:
Both the DULT protocol itself and other mechanisms specified by this working group should share the goal of not creating new vectors for tracking.

However, I offer this as a substantively neutral copy-editing change.  If you believe it would modify the scope or goals of the working group, please feel free to reject this suggestion; it's not intended as a challenge to the current consensus call.
